Text_Numeracy: For the most part, I'm pretty confident in my ability to get information about my health and use it to make decisions. The interplay between doctors, the practice they work for, insurance companies, multiple departments...etc. can be obscure at times, but not to the extent that it would seriously effect my health choices.
Text_Anxiety: It's not that I think my primary care physician is particularly untrustworthy. I just think people in general can at times be lazy, malicious, or in some way disincentivezed to help you. And it's not always easy to tell when that's the case. So I take what my doctor tells me as being probably true but potentially not the whole story, as I do with most people. For instance, I happen to know that doctors are under a lot of pressure right now to not prescribe opioids, so if my doctor tells me the best route for me is lots of ibuprofen, I'm going to be skeptical. But what other thinks am I not aware of, that might be relevant to my health? It's just best to get second opinions and take things with a grain of salt.
Text_TrustPhys: I'm just generally nervous when talking to people I'm not really familiar with, so going through the whole chain of interactions from front desk to nurse to doctor is a little bit stressful for me. But not the "I'm afraid" sort of stress. It's more of a "where do I put my hands? Why did I say that? " sort of stress.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I am not sure I understand what you mean by "knowledge of health or medical issues". However, I recently went to the emergency room for a puncture wound in my finger. There I found out that their is a portable x-ray machine nurses can take around, but they have to stand outside the room as they activate it to ovoid build-up of radiation in their body over time. I also learned that in such cases, the biggest concern for doctors is whether or not your bone was damaged, as this can lead to serious infections.

Text_Numeracy: I think that overall, I have a high capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information and services. I do generally have whichever parent is with me (I don't drive) help out with things like insurance information, but overall I feel confident in my ability to communicate with doctors and nurses.
Text_Anxiety: I have been seeing my primary care physician for many years now and we get along very well; both of us almost look forward to seeing one another. Also, her being a woman like myself helps with our rapport and my general comfort around her.
Text_TrustPhys: What makes me feel most anxious at the doctor's office is, by far, getting immunizations. While I agree to get any that are recommended, even ones that aren't strictly required by the office or by my college because I believe in taking any health precautions available to me, I am very afraid of needles and get almost pancicked when I need to have a shot.
Text_SubjectiveLit: In a class in high school, a student said that vaccines caused autism. I explained to him and the class that there was zero link between the two, and that the doctor who claimed that there was got his medical license taken away.

Text_Numeracy: i have full confidence that i can make appropriate health decisions without any assistance. if i feel i don't understand i will ask
Text_Anxiety: because i feel we have a great relationship beyond patient and dr. i feel he is my friend looking out for my health and well being
Text_TrustPhys: that something wrong is with me and it is something i can't handle by myself or an illness that will affect the rest of my life
Text_SubjectiveLit: i did research on ovarian cysts. i had the knowledge of symptoms and diet to relieve pain so when i spoke to the my doctor i was familiar with everything

Text_Numeracy: I believe that I can fill out forms sufficiently enough to get the job done. However, when it comes to family history I have a hard time remembering everything that my family has told me about their medical backgrounds. I understand most of the conditions that doctors describe to me, but I have a hard time understanding the causes of them.
Text_Anxiety: I trust my physician because she is always very personable with me. She always gives me both the ups and downs to new medications and doesn't push me to take anything that "she wouldn't take".
Text_TrustPhys: I fear having something really serious be discovered about my symptoms. For example, a few years ago I had frequent migraines and my doctor suggested that I get further testing down just to stay on the safe side. I was afraid there was a tumor.
Text_SubjectiveLit: Last summer I worked as a nanny/lifeguard for the home of a private family of two kids. One day one of the kids jumped into the deep end without my knowledge and started to drown, after I was informed he was pulled out of the pool and I started CPR as he was not breathing.

Text_Numeracy: I can understand most or all paperwork that comes from a doctors office. But if they use big medical terms that's when I need help.
Text_Anxiety: My doctor has been treating Me for years.He always treats me right and talks to me about what's going on
Text_TrustPhys: I would feel most anxious when I have been experience unknown pain and I can't explain why and I am waiting to see what the doctor say's it is
Text_SubjectiveLit: I was walking one day and my foot started hurting The way The pain was feeling I had a hunch it was gout

Text_Numeracy: I can keep up and understand what the doctor and nurse are saying. because I have taken health and science courses.
Text_Anxiety: I trust my physician because they do the best of all that they can. With telling yiu everything you want to hear.
Text_TrustPhys: I get scared of what will be bad news.wich i know is need to be heard.but its being judged secretly.
Text_SubjectiveLit: The time i pop a hip muscle they gave me the odd on how it happened then ways of testing my blood checking and looking

Text_Numeracy: I think I have a reasobly high capacity of health information.
Text_Anxiety: I have had more than one doctor.  The last one I have I get more information, but am not sure about advice.
Text_TrustPhys: I don't worry much when visiting the doctor.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I was sick with flu and stuck on work/travel.  I filly insisted home-time so I could rest, eat fruit, granola, yogurt, and take vitamin C.  I was better in less than a day after being sick for a week.

Text_Numeracy: I feel like I can read and understand basic medical information.  I feel that I can do this on my own, without any assistance.  And, I believe that I understand what is told to me or give to me to read well enough to make my own medical decisions.
Text_Anxiety: She has always listened to what problems I am having.  She runs the tests necessary to diagnose my medical conditions and my general health.  She changes medications when needed to better treat my issues.  She seems to genuinely care about my health and well being.
Text_TrustPhys: Sometimes something will be wrong with me, and we will have to wait for lab results to help figure out what is going on.  This does scare me the most.  Also, when I had one issue, it wound up later being diagnosed as bladder cancer.  The symptoms were very scary, but she did help calm me down and had me come back every day to make sure the symptoms were getting better.
Text_SubjectiveLit: Well, when I had blood in my urine, I knew I was either having a kidney problem or a bladder problem.  After having tests run, and getting to see both a kidney specialist and an urologist, it was found that I had bladder cancer.

Text_Numeracy: I think my ability to understand basic health information is above average.  I can do research online, and sometimes I have a basic idea of what needs to be done before I even go to the doctor. I nearly always understand what doctors and other health care workers tell me as long as I ask appropriate questions. The only time I don't understand health care information is when I am reading something that is overly technical.
Text_Anxiety: I do believe my doctor is honest, thorough, and careful for the most part. I think sometimes time constrictions can force her to be a little less thorough, especially when it comes to explaining why she is choosing a certain treatment. At times, I have trouble trusting doctors because I don't understand how they know the treatment they have chosen will work.
Text_TrustPhys: I am worried that they will find out I have some horrible disease, or they will give me a medication that causes bad side effects.  I also worry about how much my medical treatments will cost.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I used to be a customer service worker at a gym.  My gym offered equipment orientations to people.  The people who did the equipment orientations were supposed to have training and/or credentials that I did not have.  One night there was an equipment orientation scheduled, and the only person who was supposed to present the information had to deal with another problem.  So I started the orientation and explained how to use the treadmill safely, despite not being "properly" trained.

Text_Numeracy: I'm fairly confident and capable about talking to doctors and filling forms. I know they are  there to help and appreciate good questions and thorough statements. Some paperwork can be a bit tricky, but not overly so.
Text_Anxiety: I don't see any reason not to trust him. He's a medical professional who's been to school and been in practice for many years. It's his job to know what he's talking about.
Text_TrustPhys: Nothing really in particular, I just have doctor anxiety -- along with general anxiety. I think the doctor called it White Coat Anxiety or something like that.
Text_SubjectiveLit: My ex was a hypochondriac, so I was always learning about conditions she thought she had and trying to reassure her that she didn't

Text_Numeracy: I feel somewhat confident that I will be able to obtain, process and understand Basic health information and services needed.
Text_Anxiety: The only doctor I see is my dentist.  I HATE going to the dentist, and refused to go for decades.  Pain overrides fear to a point so I went.  I still get a nervous wreck when I go; but I trust him.   So far he has been very nice and careful.  He even gave me a free filling.
Text_TrustPhys: Both sides of my family have a history of cancer.  I don't really liked to be touched, and I hate the way I look.
Text_SubjectiveLit: 10 or so years ago; my friend said she described the symptoms of vertigo  she was suffering.  Her and her father had never heard of vertigo.  I knew from what she was saying that she was suffering from vertigo and had her cousin drive her and I to the doctors.

Text_Numeracy: Strongest degree possible. I feel I can get by with no assistance from anyone other than a tutorial.
Text_Anxiety: They seem like they are just in it for the money. Wait for an hour in the waiting room only to see the doctor for 5 minutes.
Text_TrustPhys: They talk in suspense like every single thing is bad news. Sometimes they mess up with blood work and need more blood leaving me thinking they can't do their job
Text_SubjectiveLit: Don't really know much about health other than the fact that this survey has questions that seem pointless

Text_Numeracy: Easily. All i need is to know what's wrong, and what's happening. Knowing the cause of the problem would help more.
Text_Anxiety: He is more than likely busy with multiple patients on any given business day. I don't feel like he is completely paying attention to me.
Text_TrustPhys: The costs of treatments I will need, if any. The costs of medication. Whether or not the doctor can tell how well i do or don't take care of myself. Their tone when telling me.
Text_SubjectiveLit: Getting a physical in the 9th grade. I can't remember the exact words. But i corrected a doctor on something to do with the heart.

Text_Numeracy: I think i can understand most of what is said. If not i research online to gather more information. That tends to lead to more question so then I call the doctor to get clarification.
Text_Anxiety: I do not have a primary care provider. i normally go to urgent care if I am sick or if I have an issue that needs to be addressed.
Text_TrustPhys: Getting an uncertain or negative diagnoses would cause worry or anxiety. For myself or a loved one. THe feelings are the same
Text_SubjectiveLit: A co-worker had a family member that had a medical diagnoses ad was told by the dr they could not have that diagnoses because it would have been cause for emergency surgery.  I informed this co-worker that it was absolutely possible the diagnoses was correct and that there is a small population of people who have the same thing and because of  other medical issues they may have they are not a candidate for the surgery right away.

Text_Numeracy: I CAN UNDERSTAND MST THINGS BUT SOMETIMES NEED TO USE THE INTERNET FOR A MORE THOUROUGH EXPLAINATION
Text_Anxiety: Doctor never listens to concerns and basically acts superior does not explain anything and rarely rechecks if I still have the symptoms
Text_TrustPhys: I am concerned that I will not be listened to and the doctor will not take symptoms serious enough to find out what is causing them. The doctor makes you feel as if you do not know how your body feels
Text_SubjectiveLit: I have a pinched nerve in neck and know when inflamation is severe and am able to ease the pain by doing isometrics. I know the immune system requires certain vitamins to be effective. I also think the medical people do not take ordinary people seriously enough

Text_Numeracy: I definately have the capacity to obtain, process and understand basic health information.  However, I do have difficulty trying to have discussions on this health information with my health care providers.   He would rather joke and laugh, then be available to answer questions.  And if I call on phone, I cannot get a hold of a knowledgable person.
Text_Anxiety: He would rather talk about himself and laugh at his jokes than pay attention to my needs.  I can get whatever prescription I would like, just by asking. He doesn't remember from one visit to the next anything about me.  When he is not laughing and not paying attention, he has his nose in that stupid computer of it.
Text_TrustPhys: I know that he is going to complain about my weight.  Then he is going to tell me that his wife put him on a diet and how small his plate is.  He will then tell me that his wife is blond and beautiful and that she knows what is best.  Then he will talk about his need to still lose ten pounds so that his wife will be proud of him.....every time I go see him.....same story.....
Text_SubjectiveLit: My husband had become very mean to me.   This is really unlike him.  So I brought him to the doctor, who said everything was fine.   His behavior continued, so I brought him to the ER and insisted he be checked over.  After blood and urine was drawn, come to find out he was septic.

Text_Numeracy: I think I have basic understanding of health information presented to me. I can comprehend the information given to me and most of the time understand how to make the appropriate decisions regarding my health
Text_Anxiety: I do not trust or distrust my doctor. They are only human and are capable of making mistakes so I trust my doctor but if necessary I will opt for a second opinion if I am uncomfortable with anything
Text_TrustPhys: A great major of the time I am not worried just anxious for a diagnosis and resolution because I normal google my symptoms and come up with the most extreme possibility
Text_SubjectiveLit: Being human, having my share of emergency room visits, and a few minor medical issues earlier in life. Later on going through pregnancy and delivering a child

Text_Numeracy: I usually do research before I visited the doctor so I know what I'm up against.  If the doctor brings up something new and I don't understand it, then I will ask.  I want to know what is going on with me.
Text_Anxiety: Before she retired, I had a good relationship with my former primary care.  She was very open with me and worked with me to better my help.  I really trusted her.  Now she is gone and I'm back at square one with no one I trust.
Text_TrustPhys: Having to sit on the exam table.  I'm a big guy and it is tough to get on that thing and sit.  I would rather sit in the chair.
Text_SubjectiveLit: Every time I have an extreme pain in my back flank then I know I have a kidney stone.  Then I get to go to the hospital, have the nurse completely not trust me thinking I'm addicted to pain killers so I get to sit in agony until they finally believe me.

Text_Numeracy: I confident that I would be able to understand most of the basic health information and services I need from my doctor
Text_Anxiety: The doctors I've gone to are usually right. They've never given any reason for me to not trust them, and they've always been honest with me, even if I didn't want to hear it.
Text_TrustPhys: I've never liked going to the doctor's. They usually just tell things I already know, but it doesn't make me feel any less uncomfortable. I don't think I'll ever be ready the day they tell me something I won't know about my physical condition
Text_SubjectiveLit: I demonstrated my medical knowledge during a test in high school. We learned CPR in my health class and I demonstrated how to proceed to receive a certificate

Text_Numeracy: I feel I am very good with the information my doctor provides me. I even research on Google and if I have questions I call my nurse or doctor to help explain.
Text_Anxiety: I trust my doctor because she is very careful when it comes to my treatment. I believe that if it wasnt for her quick thinking and action my premature son might not be alive today. After that pregnancy I decided to stick with her.
Text_TrustPhys: The diagnosis. I have very unhealthy habits and when I have aches or pains in those areas I always assume the worst. But after my check up it's usually nothing or something minor that can be taken care of with prescription medications.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I really can't say. I do not believe math questions should be on a survey. What is this a test? I thought I was supposed to just give my opinion.
